handDesc.p: Halantas. Final K in l32. Final T is a full-sized ta-shape without a headmark, with a curly tail; specimens in l8, l30; N in l10 (indistinct), l18, l24, l37, l39, l52. Final M is a raised circle at headline height, larger than an anusvāra, with a curly tail on top; specimens in l5, l7, l9, l11, l12, l51, l54, l55, l60. Jihvāmūlīya in l42, l51; upadhmānīya in l10, l41, l43, l46, l51.

Original punctuation marks are straight verticals of body height, with a headmark. @@@provisionally /, replace with markup. The second bar of the punctuation mark after l3 kṣite seems to have a curly upward extension like a repha and should perhaps be re-classified as an ornate one.

Other palaeographic observations. Anusvāra is normally at headline height after the character to which it belongs. Medial o is normally written with the cursive single stroke; a composite stroke like e and ā combined occurs e.g. in l9 viṣṇuvarddhano. Au is not distinguished from the cursive o in any apparent way, and in my edition I show this as a scribal mistake. Hypersandhi in l13 samāṣṭabhiḥ (for samā aṣṭabhiḥ).

app.note: The e is clear in the estampage, though not in the photo.

Though shown as clear by both editors, the first and third character in this line are vague in both surrogates available to me and ya occupies fairly narrow space. Some correction may have taken place here, possibly from a haplographic jayasiha or joyasiha.

Shown as clear by both editors, these characters are not really legible in the available facsimiles. In Venugopaul Chetty's photo they could with some imagination be tajjeṣṭo (for tajjyeṣṭho), but the photo was in all probability retouched by hand, since it exhibits some other strange glyph shapes where Hultzsch's estampage shows the expected shapes. In this case, the t of tro is quite clear in the estampage, so the reading (shared by Venugopaul Chetty) is probably correct.
